titleproper.value:
Preliminary Inventory to the Clarence Reed Papers
                    <num>WAG.015</num>

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-29T20:25-0400</date>

p.value: Clarence Reed was born in New York City in 1909. After working at odd jobs in the army, in lumber camps, and on the railroad, he became active in the Unemployed Councils and the Friends of the Soviet Union in the 1930s. He found work with a shipping company during World War II, when he joined the National Maritime Union. After the War, Reed was expelled from the Communist Party and helped establish a rank and file committee in the NMU. The rank and file committee ran slates of candidates against the incumbent union leadership and concentrated on the problems of corruption and drugs within the NMU's ranks.

The collection consists mainly of correspondence and other material regarding Reed's activity in the National Maritime Union and his 1973-74 campaign for union office. Also included are union constitutions, copies of cartoons by Reed on union issues, and miscellaneous correspondence. The archives also has an oral history interview and a play written by Reed in 1984.

subject.value: Merchant mariners |x Labor unions |z United States.
